Why do independent-minded people need protection?
What happens when conventional-minded people gain power?
How does restricting certain ideas affect innovation?

essays.title: The Founder Visa
essays.summary: Paul Graham proposes creating a special visa category for startup founders, arguing it would significantly boost the US economy at virtually no cost. He suggests allowing 10,000 founders annually, who would be restricted to founding new companies rather than taking existing jobs, with startup investors determining visa eligibility.
questions_answered: What policy change could most increase US startups?
How should the government identify legitimate startup founders?
Would immigrant founders take jobs from Americans?

essays.title: The Fatal Pinch
essays.summary: This essay describes the 'fatal pinch' - a dangerous situation where startups have money but are burning through it with minimal revenue growth, relying on the false hope of raising more funding. Graham provides practical survival strategies including cutting expenses, firing unnecessary staff, pivoting to consulting work, and most importantly, recognizing that the probability of raising more money in this situation is effectively zero.
questions_answered: What is the fatal pinch and how do I recognize it?
What should I do if my startup is running out of money?
Should I try to raise more funding or focus on profitability?
When should I consider pivoting to consulting work?

essays.title: The Equity Equation
essays.summary: This essay presents a mathematical formula (1/(1 - n)) for determining whether trading equity for investment, employees, or deals is worthwhile. The core principle is that any equity trade should increase the value of your remaining shares enough to make you net ahead.
questions_answered: How much equity should I give to investors?
How much stock should I give to employees?
When is an equity trade worth it?
How do I calculate the value of giving up equity?

essays.title: The Bus Ticket Theory of Genius
essays.summary: The 'bus ticket theory' of genius proposes that great work requires not just ability and determination, but an obsessive, disinterested fascination with a particular topic that matters. This obsession, like a bus ticket collector's passion for minutiae, drives people to explore unpromising paths that lead to breakthrough discoveries, suggesting that cultivating genuine interests may be key to doing exceptional work.
questions_answered: What is the third ingredient for doing great work besides ability and determination?
Why do some people make groundbreaking discoveries while others don't?
How can we encourage genius and great work?
Why do people do less great work after having children?

essays.title: The Best Essay
essays.summary: An exploration of what makes the ideal essay, concluding that great essays come from discovering important ideas through a recursive process of asking novel questions and rigorously pursuing their answers. The essay demonstrates its own thesis by evolving from discussing 'the best essay' to explaining the mechanics of effective essay writing itself.
questions_answered: What makes an essay great?
How do you discover ideas through writing?
Why do some essays remain timeless while others don't?
How should you choose what to write about?

essays.title: The Anatomy of Determination
essays.summary: Determination, not intelligence, is the most important predictor of startup success. It consists of three components: willfulness (innate drive), discipline (which can be cultivated), and ambition (highly malleable through peer influence and achievements).
questions_answered: What's the most important predictor of startup success?
Can determination be developed or is it innate?
What are the components of determination?
Why do some smart people fail while others succeed?

essays.title: The Airbnbs
essays.summary: Paul Graham reflects on what made Airbnb's founders special during their YC days - their extraordinary earnestness, work ethic, and persistence despite having maxed-out credit cards and no growth for a year. The founders' personal experience as the first hosts convinced them they had discovered something revolutionary, which kept them going through the worst recession in decades until they achieved ramen profitability.
questions_answered: Why didn't Airbnb's founders give up despite a year of no growth?
What was special about Airbnb's founders?
How did Airbnb achieve initial growth?
What role did personal experience play in founder motivation?

essays.title: The Age of the Essay
essays.summary: This essay explores what a real essay is—not the rigid school format defending a thesis, but an exploratory form of writing where you discover ideas through the process itself. Graham traces the historical accidents that led to literature professors teaching writing and explains how true essays meander through interesting questions to find surprising insights, contrasting this with the artificial defend-a-position essays taught in schools.
questions_answered: What is the difference between real essays and school essays?
Why do schools teach essay writing the way they do?
How should you approach writing a real essay?
Why is surprise important in essay writing?

essays.title: The Acceleration of Addictiveness
essays.summary: Technological progress accelerates the creation of addictive things by concentrating substances and experiences into more potent forms, from drugs to social media. As the world becomes more addictive, living well will require increasingly deliberate choices to say no, making those who resist seem eccentric by societal standards.
questions_answered: Why is the world becoming more addictive?
How does technological progress create addiction?
What strategies can we use to avoid new addictions?
Why will living well seem increasingly eccentric?

essays.title: The 18 Mistakes That Kill Startups
essays.summary: This essay presents 18 common mistakes that cause startups to fail, emphasizing that the root cause is not making something users want. Graham provides actionable advice on avoiding pitfalls ranging from team composition and location choices to fundraising and product development strategies.
questions_answered: What are the most common mistakes that kill startups?
How much money should a startup raise?
When should you launch your product?
Why do most startups fail?

essays.title: Tablets
essays.summary: Graham argues that tablets (iPads and iPhones) will become the universal computing platform, replacing numerous special-purpose devices through software applications. He introduces Buckminster Fuller's concept of 'ephemeralization' - physical machinery being replaced by software - as the driving force behind tablets' inevitable dominance.
questions_answered: What will we call iPhones and iPads collectively?
Why will tablets dominate the future of computing?
How can competitors challenge Apple's dominance in tablets?
What opportunities exist for startups in the tablet era?

essays.title: Superlinear Returns
essays.summary: This essay explores how returns for performance are often superlinear rather than linear, meaning that small differences in performance lead to disproportionately large differences in outcomes. Graham explains the two fundamental causes of superlinear returns (exponential growth and thresholds) and provides guidance on how ambitious individuals can take advantage of them.
questions_answered: Why do small performance differences lead to huge outcome differences?
How can ambitious individuals benefit from superlinear returns?
What types of work have superlinear returns?
Why is learning so important for achieving exceptional outcomes?

essays.title: Subject: Airbnb
essays.summary: A fascinating email exchange between Paul Graham and Fred Wilson about Airbnb in early 2009, showing how VCs initially struggled to see the startup's potential. The correspondence reveals PG's persistent advocacy for the founders while Fred and his partners debated the viability of the accommodation marketplace concept.
questions_answered: How do investors evaluate early-stage startups?
What did early Airbnb investor conversations look like?

Why do VCs sometimes miss great opportunities?

essays.title: Stuff
essays.summary: This essay explores how material possessions have become overabundant and undervalued in modern society, arguing that accumulating stuff often creates more burden than benefit. Graham reflects on his personal experience with overconsumption and offers practical strategies for resisting the urge to acquire unnecessary possessions.
questions_answered: Why do we accumulate so much unnecessary stuff?
How does clutter affect our mental state?
What strategies can help resist buying unnecessary things?
How has our relationship with material goods changed historically?

essays.title: Startups in 13 Sentences
essays.summary: Paul Graham distills startup wisdom into 13 essential principles, emphasizing the critical importance of understanding users above all else. He covers everything from choosing cofounders and launching quickly to maintaining morale and achieving ramen profitability, providing a comprehensive guide for early-stage startups.
questions_answered: What are the most important principles for startup success?
How should startups approach user engagement?
What mistakes should early-stage startups avoid?
Why is understanding users the most critical startup principle?

essays.title: Startup = Growth
essays.summary: This essay defines startups as companies designed to grow fast, arguing that growth is the only essential characteristic that distinguishes startups from other businesses. Graham explains that startups need to make something lots of people want and reach all those people, and suggests using weekly growth rates (5-7% for good performance) as the primary metric to guide all startup decisions.
questions_answered: What defines a startup?
What growth rate should startups target?
How is a startup different from a regular business?
How should founders make decisions?

essays.title: Some Heroes
essays.summary: Paul Graham shares a personal list of his heroes, each characterized by two key qualities: caring almost excessively about their work and being absolutely honest. The essay profiles diverse figures from Jack Lambert to Steve Jobs, exploring what made each of them exceptional and how they influenced Graham's thinking.
questions_answered: What qualities define true heroes?

What connects seemingly diverse successful people?

essays.title: Six Principles for Making New Things
essays.summary: Paul Graham presents six principles for creating successful new things: find simple solutions to overlooked problems that actually need solving, deliver them informally, start with a crude version, and iterate rapidly. These principles often generate contemptuous initial reactions because simple solutions don't seem impressive and overlooked problems appear unimportant, but this contrarian approach ultimately leads to discovering genuinely innovative solutions.

essays.title: Schlep Blindness
essays.summary: Schlep blindness is an unconscious tendency to avoid seeing startup ideas that involve tedious, unpleasant work (schleps), even when these ideas are valuable and obvious. The phenomenon explains why many founders overlook important problems like payment processing in favor of easier but less impactful ideas, and suggests that embracing difficult work can lead to less competition and greater success.

essays.title: Return of the Mac
essays.summary: Paul Graham observes that top hackers are switching back to Macs with the introduction of OS X, which combines beautiful hardware design with a powerful Unix-based operating system. He argues that what hackers adopt today becomes mainstream technology in 10 years, suggesting Apple's resurgence among technical users predicts broader market success.

essays.title: Relentlessly Resourceful
essays.summary: Defines the essential quality of a successful startup founder as being 'relentlessly resourceful' - combining determination with flexibility to overcome novel obstacles. This quality involves continuously adapting and trying new approaches rather than just pushing through problems blindly.

essays.title: Ramen Profitable
essays.summary: Ramen profitability is a concept where a startup makes just enough revenue to cover the founders' basic living expenses, typically around $3000/month. This minimal profitability is significant because it gives founders time and removes their dependency on investors, allowing them to raise money on their own terms rather than out of necessity.

essays.title: RSS

questions_answered: How can I get an RSS feed of Paul Graham's essays?

essays.title: Putting Ideas into Words
essays.summary: Writing forces you to clarify and complete your ideas, revealing that what seemed clear in your head is often imprecise or incomplete. The process of putting ideas into words is a severe test that transforms thoughts, and no one has fully formed ideas about complex topics without writing about them.

essays.title: Programming Bottom-Up
essays.summary: This essay introduces the concept of bottom-up programming, primarily using Lisp, where instead of just breaking a program down from the top, you build the language up toward your problem domain. This approach results in smaller, more flexible programs with better code reuse and clarity.

essays.title: Post-Medium Publishing
essays.summary: Publishers have always been in the business of selling physical media rather than content itself, and as digital distribution makes the medium obsolete, they struggle to find new business models. The future likely lies in either giving content away and monetizing indirectly through advertising and merchandise, or finding ways to embody information in physical forms that people value.

essays.title: Persuade xor Discover
essays.summary: Graham argues that writing to persuade and writing to discover truth are fundamentally opposed goals. He explains why he chooses to write bluntly to figure things out rather than adding diplomatic padding to make ideas more palatable, even though this approach may offend readers.

essays.title: Organic Startup Ideas
essays.summary: This essay explains that the best startup ideas grow organically from solving your own problems, like Apple did, rather than trying to guess what others need. Young founders should focus on fixing what's broken in their daily lives, even if the ideas initially seem like toys, as these organic ideas are more likely to succeed than made-up ones.

essays.title: Novelty and Heresy

He suggests that individual talent and effort matter much more than college prestige, and that the real tragedy is people's insecurity about not attending elite schools.

essays.title: Modeling a Wealth Tax

essays.title: Mind the Gap

Graham challenges the childhood 'Daddy Model' of wealth distribution, explaining how the rise of the middle class transformed wealth from a zero-sum game based on theft to value creation through technology and innovation.

essays.title: Microsoft is Dead
essays.summary: An analysis of Microsoft's decline from technology dominance to irrelevance, marking the company as 'dead' in terms of innovation and influence by the mid-2000s. Graham attributes this decline to four simultaneous factors: Google's rise, the shift to web applications, broadband adoption, and Apple's resurgence.

essays.title: Mean People Fail
essays.summary: Being mean is inversely correlated with success, particularly in startups, because meanness makes you stupid, prevents you from attracting top talent, and conflicts with the benevolent motivation needed to build great things. The world is shifting from zero-sum games where meanness was an advantage to positive-sum games based on new ideas and creation, where meanness is a handicap.

essays.title: Maker's Schedule, Manager's Schedule
essays.summary: This essay explains the fundamental conflict between two different work schedules: the maker's schedule (used by programmers and writers who need long uninterrupted blocks of time) and the manager's schedule (which operates in one-hour intervals). It describes how meetings are particularly destructive for makers because they break up the day into pieces too small to do meaningful creative work, and offers office hours as a solution to manage this conflict.

essays.title: Life is Short
essays.summary: Life is genuinely short when measured in discrete moments rather than continuous time, and this realization should drive us to eliminate bullshit from our lives and focus on what truly matters. The essay argues for consciously avoiding time-wasters, prioritizing meaningful experiences, and not waiting to pursue important goals.

essays.title: Lies We Tell Kids
essays.summary: An exploration of the various lies adults tell children, examining the motivations behind them (protection, maintaining innocence, cultural identity, authority) and arguing that adults should consciously identify and clear out the lies they were told as children to better understand reality.

essays.title: Keep Your Identity Small
essays.summary: Paul Graham argues that discussions about politics and religion become unproductive because these topics engage people's identities, making them partisan and unable to think clearly. He suggests that the best way to have better ideas is to keep your identity small by avoiding labels and letting as few things as possible become part of your identity.

essays.title: Jessica Livingston

essays.title: Is It Worth Being Wise?
essays.summary: This essay explores the relationship between wisdom and intelligence, arguing that wisdom represents consistent good judgment across many situations (high average), while intelligence represents exceptional performance in specific areas (high peaks). Graham suggests that as knowledge becomes more specialized, we increasingly have to choose between cultivating wisdom through discipline and self-control versus intelligence through focused curiosity and accepting discontentment.

essays.title: Investor Herd Dynamics

Graham describes how this creates exponential growth patterns in investment interest and warns founders not to mistake these stampedes as the essence of fundraising success.

essays.title: If Lisp is So Great

He explains that Lisp's unfamiliar syntax intimidates newcomers, and that network effects and management preferences tend to reinforce the popularity of mainstream languages.

essays.title: How to Write Usefully

essays.title: How to Work Hard

essays.title: How to Think for Yourself

He argues that independent-mindedness is largely innate and crucial to consider when choosing a career path, warning that most people misjudge their own position on the conventional-to-independent spectrum.

essays.title: How to Raise Money

essays.title: How to Lose Time and Money
essays.summary: Paul Graham explores how wealth and time are lost not through obvious self-indulgence, but through bad investments and fake work that bypass our natural alarms. He argues that while we have built-in warnings against pleasure-seeking, the modern world requires developing new alarms for subtler traps that mimic productive behavior.

essays.title: How to Get Startup Ideas

essays.title: How to Do What You Love

essays.summary: Graham examines philosophy's historical problems and proposes a new approach, arguing that most philosophical debates are driven by linguistic confusion and that philosophy should focus on discovering useful general truths rather than pursuing abstract knowledge for its own sake. essays.title: How to Do Great Work

essays.title: How to Do Great Work

essays.title: How to Convince Investors
essays.summary: This essay explains how founders should convince investors by being genuinely formidable and truthful about their startup's potential. essays.title: How to Be an Expert in a Changing World
essays.summary: In a rapidly changing world, experts often become wrong by clinging to outdated beliefs. The key to staying relevant is to be aggressively open-minded, avoid letting hypotheses harden into rigid beliefs, and focus on backing innovative people rather than specific ideas.

essays.title: How You Know

Why should we reread important books?

essays.title: How Y Combinator Started
essays.summary: The founding story of Y Combinator, which began in March 2005 when Paul Graham and Jessica Livingston decided to create a new type of seed investment firm while walking home from dinner. They raised $200k from four founders and pioneered the concept of funding startups synchronously in batches, starting with a summer program that unexpectedly produced successful companies.
questions_answered: How did Y Combinator get started?
Why was batch funding revolutionary for startups?
What made YC different from traditional VC firms?
How did YC evolve from Cambridge Seed to a Silicon Valley institution?

essays.title: How People Get Rich Now
essays.summary: An analysis of how wealth creation has shifted from inheritance and traditional industries like oil and real estate in 1982 to technology startups today. Graham argues this isn't an anomaly but a return to historical norms after mid-20th century consolidation, with startups becoming easier and cheaper to launch, growing faster, and creating more wealth than ever before.
questions_answered: How has wealth creation changed from 1982 to 2020?
Why are tech founders getting so rich so young?
Is increasing wealth inequality inevitable with more startups?
Why were there fewer startup founders in 1982?

essays.title: How Art Can Be Good
essays.summary: Paul Graham argues that good art is not subjective but can be objectively measured by how well it engages its human audience, who share common perceptual and cognitive traits. He dismantles relativism in art by showing that humans have universal reactions to certain visual elements, making some art objectively better than others.
questions_answered: Is taste in art purely subjective?
Can there be objective standards for good art?
Why do humans share common reactions to certain art?
How can artists develop better taste?

essays.title: Holding a Program in One's Head
essays.summary: This essay explores how programmers achieve deep understanding by holding entire programs in their heads, similar to mathematicians with problems. Graham identifies eight key practices that enable this mental model, from avoiding distractions to working in small groups, and argues that traditional organizations inadvertently prevent these practices, creating opportunities for startups.
questions_answered: How can programmers be more productive?
Why do programmers prefer working alone or in small teams?
What working conditions enable deep understanding of code?
Why are large organizations often inefficient at software development?

essays.title: High Resolution Fundraising
essays.summary: This essay explains how convertible notes enable high-resolution fundraising by allowing startups to offer different terms to different investors, breaking the deadlock that occurs when investors wait to see who else is investing. Graham argues that flexible pricing based on investor value and timing is the future of fundraising, replacing fixed-size equity rounds.
questions_answered: Why are convertible notes becoming more popular?
How can startups break investor deadlocks?
Why should different investors get different prices?
What are the problems with fixed-size equity rounds?

essays.title: Heresy
essays.summary: Paul Graham examines the resurgence of heresy as a concept in modern society, where expressing certain opinions can lead to social and professional punishment regardless of their truth value. He argues that waves of intolerance require both intolerant people and unifying ideologies, and while freedom of expression has narrowed recently, he remains optimistic about long-term trends.
questions_answered: Why has the concept of heresy returned in modern times?
What are the structural characteristics that define a heresy?
How do waves of intolerance form and spread?
What is the relationship between truth and accusations of heresy?

essays.title: Having Kids
essays.summary: Paul Graham reflects on how having children transformed his perspective from dreading parenthood to finding it deeply fulfilling. Despite the real challenges of reduced productivity and shifted ambitions, he discovers that the actual experience brings unexpected joy, peace, and meaningful moments that outweigh the freedoms he gave up.
questions_answered: How does having kids change your perspective on life?
Does having kids make you less ambitious?
Is the loss of freedom from having kids worth it?
Why do parents seem happy despite the challenges?

essays.title: Having Kids
essays.summary: Paul Graham reflects on how his perspective on parenthood dramatically changed after having children, discovering unexpected joys and peace despite the loss of some productivity and freedom. He admits that while having kids reduces ambition and productivity, the actual moments of happiness and connection far exceed what he experienced before becoming a parent.
questions_answered: How does having kids change your perspective on life?
Does having children reduce productivity and ambition?
Why do non-parents often dread having kids?
What are the unexpected benefits of parenthood?

essays.title: Good and Bad Procrastination
essays.summary: Paul Graham argues that procrastination isn't inherently bad when you're avoiding small tasks to work on important problems. He identifies three types of procrastination and advocates for 'type-C' procrastination where you put off errands to focus on ambitious, meaningful work that requires uninterrupted time and inspiration.
questions_answered: Is procrastination always bad?
How can you procrastinate effectively?
Why is it hard to work on big problems?
What's the difference between productive and unproductive procrastination?

essays.title: Good Writing
essays.summary: This essay argues that good writing—writing that sounds good and flows well—is more likely to contain correct ideas. Graham demonstrates how the aesthetic quality of writing and the accuracy of ideas are interconnected, with better rhythm and flow serving as both a constraint that improves ideas and a tool for detecting errors.
questions_answered: Why does good-sounding writing tend to be more accurate?
How does rewriting improve both style and substance?
What's the connection between writing rhythm and idea quality?
Can beautiful writing still be false?

essays.title: General and Surprising
essays.summary: Explores the value of insights that are both general and surprising, arguing that even small additions of novelty to general ideas can be valuable. Suggests that writers shouldn't worry about repeating themselves when working with general concepts, as small variations can lead to important new discoveries.
questions_answered: How do you create valuable insights?
Should you worry about repeating yourself in writing?
What makes an idea worthwhile even if it seems familiar?

essays.title: Frighteningly Ambitious Startup Ideas
essays.summary: Paul Graham explores seven frighteningly ambitious startup ideas that could make founders billionaires but are psychologically intimidating. He argues that the biggest startup ideas tend to repel rather than attract people, and suggests approaching them obliquely by starting with deceptively small implementations rather than making frontal attacks.
questions_answered: Why do the biggest startup ideas feel scary?
How should founders approach frighteningly ambitious ideas?
What are some potentially billion-dollar startup opportunities?

essays.title: Founder Mode
essays.summary: Paul Graham explores the distinction between 'founder mode' and 'manager mode' in running companies, arguing that conventional wisdom about scaling startups through traditional management practices is flawed. He suggests that founders have unique capabilities that professional managers lack, and that successful founders like Brian Chesky and Steve Jobs have discovered more effective ways to run large companies by breaking traditional management rules.
questions_answered: Why does traditional management advice fail founders?
How should founders run companies as they scale?
What's the difference between founder mode and manager mode?
Why do founders feel gaslit when following conventional management wisdom?

essays.title: Founder Control
essays.summary: Examines the shifting trend of founders maintaining board control after Series A funding, arguing that what was once rare is becoming increasingly common among successful startups. Graham predicts this will become the new norm as VCs realize that trusting strong founders is better than trying to control them.
questions_answered: How common is it for founders to keep board control after Series A?
Why are VCs resistant to founders keeping board control?
How is the norm changing for startup board composition?
What does board control actually mean in practice?

essays.title: Five Founders
essays.summary: Paul Graham reflects on the five startup founders who have influenced him most over the past 30 years, highlighting their unique contributions to startup culture and thinking. He emphasizes what made each founder exceptional, from Steve Jobs' design sense to Paul Buchheit's principle of making a small number of users love your product.
questions_answered: Who are the most influential startup founders?
What qualities make a founder exceptional?
What lessons can be learned from successful founders?

essays.title: Fierce Nerds
essays.summary: This essay defines and explores 'fierce nerds' - highly competitive, intelligent, and socially awkward individuals who combine nerdiness with intense drive. Graham argues that while their fierce qualities can lead to great success in solving hard problems and building companies, without productive outlets this fierceness can turn to bitterness.
questions_answered: What distinguishes fierce nerds from regular nerds?
How can fierce nerds avoid becoming bitter?
Why are fierce nerds increasingly successful in business?
What qualities make fierce nerds effective problem solvers?

essays.title: Fashionable Problems
essays.summary: Most people, even the brightest minds, work on fashionable problems in their fields, leaving vast unexplored possibilities. The best opportunities lie in apparently exhausted fields approached with fresh perspectives, and genuine passion for your work is the best defense against following the crowd.
questions_answered: Why do smart people work on similar problems?
Where can you find untapped opportunities?
How can you avoid following the crowd in your work?

essays.title: Economic Inequality
essays.summary: Examines the nuanced nature of economic inequality, arguing that it has multiple causes—some beneficial (like successful startups) and others harmful (like tax loopholes)—and that understanding these distinctions is crucial for addressing the problem effectively. Challenges the common oversimplification of treating all inequality as uniformly bad.
questions_answered: Should we reduce all forms of economic inequality?
Is helping startups contribute to harmful inequality?
Why do people oversimplify economic inequality?
What are the different causes of economic inequality?

essays.title: Earnestness
essays.summary: Paul Graham explores why earnestness—genuine interest in problems for their own sake rather than for fame or money—is the most important quality he and Jessica Livingston look for in startup founders. He argues that while earnestness may seem naive or unfashionable, it provides the deep motivation and resilience needed for success, especially as business has become more intellectually interesting and aligned with genuine curiosity.
key_concepts: alignment of intellectual curiosity and money
questions_answered: Why does earnestness matter so much in Silicon Valley?
What motivates the best startup founders?
How has the relationship between intellectual curiosity and business changed?
Why do nerds often become successful entrepreneurs?

essays.title: Early Work
essays.summary: This essay explores how the fear of creating something that seems lame or unimpressive prevents people from doing great work, arguing that most ambitious projects go through an embarrassing early stage. Graham suggests that this fear is not deeply rooted and can be overcome, using Silicon Valley as an example of a culture that has learned to be optimistic about strange-sounding new ideas rather than dismissive.
key_concepts: switching polarity from criticism to optimism
questions_answered: Why do people hold back from doing great work?
How can we overcome the fear of creating something that seems unimpressive?
Why does Silicon Valley have a more accepting attitude toward new ideas?
What role does culture play in supporting or dismissing innovation?

essays.title: Donate Unrestricted
essays.summary: Paul Graham argues that restricted donations to nonprofits are inherently suboptimal because the nonprofits themselves understand better than donors where money needs to be spent. He explains that donors often restrict donations for personal reasons like publicity rather than effectiveness, and encourages donors to trust nonprofits with unrestricted donations.
questions_answered: Why are restricted donations problematic?
When are restricted donations acceptable?
Why do donors make restricted donations despite their limitations?

essays.title: Don't Talk to Corp Dev
essays.summary: Paul Graham warns founders against talking to corporate development teams unless they're ready to sell immediately, as these conversations are incredibly distracting and often manipulative. Corp dev teams employ brutal negotiation tactics to acquire companies cheaply, and the process can severely damage startup morale and focus at critical growth stages.
questions_answered: When should startups talk to corporate development?
Why do corp dev meetings harm startups?
What tactics do corp dev teams use?
How can founders protect themselves from acquisition distractions?

essays.title: Do Things that Don't Scale
essays.summary: Paul Graham argues that successful startups must initially do things that don't scale, particularly manual user recruitment and providing extraordinary customer service. While these unscalable activities seem laborious and inefficient, they create the momentum needed for sustainable growth and shape the company's DNA permanently.
questions_answered: How should early-stage startups acquire their first users?
Why do founders resist doing unscalable things?
What mistakes do inexperienced founders make about growth?

essays.title: Disconnecting Distraction
essays.summary: An essay about how internet-based distractions have evolved to become more addictive and harder to avoid than traditional time-wasters like TV. Graham describes his personal struggle with online procrastination and experiments with separating his work and internet-browsing computers to combat distraction.
questions_answered: Why has the internet become so distracting?
How do distractions evolve to target procrastinators?
What strategies can help avoid online distractions?

essays.title: Defining Property
essays.summary: This essay explores how the definition of property changes over time based on what works in practice, using the metaphor of charging for smells to illustrate how digital content distribution has fundamentally changed with networks. Graham argues that the RIAA and MPAA's aggressive legal tactics against file sharing are evidence that their definition of property no longer works in the digital age.
questions_answered: How does the definition of property change over time?
Why are traditional content distributors struggling with digital piracy?
When should people be able to charge for content?
What makes a definition of property 'work' in society?

essays.title: Default Alive or Default Dead?
essays.summary: This essay introduces the critical concept of being 'default alive' (reaching profitability with current resources and growth) versus 'default dead' for startups, emphasizing that many founders don't know their status. It warns against the 'fatal pinch' caused by overhiring and slow growth, arguing that startups should focus on product improvement rather than rapid hiring to achieve sustainable growth.
questions_answered: How do I know if my startup will survive?
When should a startup hire more people?
Why do startups with funding often fail?
How can startups avoid the fatal pinch?

essays.title: Crazy New Ideas
essays.summary: This essay explores why reasonable domain experts proposing seemingly crazy ideas deserve serious consideration rather than dismissal, as historically many revolutionary ideas started this way. Graham argues that the tendency to dismiss new ideas stems from envy, desire to appear sophisticated, vested interests, and the pervasive influence of current paradigms on our thinking.
key_concepts: asymmetry between new and established ideas
questions_answered: Why do smart people propose ideas that sound crazy?
Why do people dismiss revolutionary ideas?
How can we better evaluate potentially groundbreaking ideas?
What makes some crazy-sounding ideas worth pursuing?

essays.title: Coronavirus and Credibility
essays.summary: This essay examines how the coronavirus pandemic exposed the credibility of media figures and politicians who made false predictions about its severity. Graham argues that epidemics uniquely reveal who lacks credibility because they rapidly and unequivocally falsify incorrect predictions, unlike typical punditry where accountability is rare.
questions_answered: Why do pundits make confident false predictions?
How do epidemics expose credibility differently than other events?
What makes the pandemic a unique test of credibility?

essays.title: Charisma / Power
essays.summary: This essay explores the relationship between power and charisma, explaining why powerful but uncharismatic people tend to be disliked and become targets for criticism. It argues that builder-type leaders who lack schmoozing skills may actually be the best for their roles despite the criticism they attract.
questions_answered: Why are powerful but uncharismatic people often disliked?
Is being criticized always a sign of poor leadership?
What's the difference between builder and schmoozer type leaders?

essays.title: Change Your Name
essays.summary: Paul Graham argues that startups without the .com domain of their company name should change their name, as not having it signals weakness and marginality. He explains that founders resist this advice due to emotional attachment and inability to imagine alternatives, but emphasizes that finding a new name with an available .com is both important and achievable.
questions_answered: Why is having a .com domain important for startups?
Why do founders resist changing their company name?
How can startups find better names with available domains?

essays.title: Can You Buy a Silicon Valley?  Maybe.
essays.summary: Examines whether cities can artificially create their own Silicon Valley by funding startups. Argues that while organic growth through universities is how Silicon Valley emerged, strategic funding at the right stage could potentially work if cities fund startups sufficiently so they don't need to relocate.
questions_answered: Can cities recreate Silicon Valley artificially?
Why don't seed accelerators create regional startup hubs?
What stage should cities fund startups to keep them local?

essays.title: Black Swan Farming
essays.summary: Startup investing is deeply counterintuitive because returns are concentrated in a tiny number of huge winners (1000x returns), and the best startup ideas initially look like bad ideas. Y Combinator must fight their instincts to fund enough risky-looking startups to find the rare black swans like Dropbox and Airbnb.
questions_answered: Why do the best startups initially seem like bad ideas?
How concentrated are returns in venture capital?
Why is fundraising success a misleading metric for investors?
What makes startup investing so counterintuitive?

essays.title: Billionaires Build
essays.summary: This essay explains how to succeed in a Y Combinator interview while simultaneously refuting the claim that billionaires become wealthy by exploiting people. Graham argues that successful founders and billionaires are driven by genuine interest in solving user problems and building something they care about, not exploitation.
questions_answered: How do you ace a Y Combinator interview?
What qualities do successful billionaire founders have?
Is exploitation necessary to become a billionaire?
What do VCs look for in founders?

essays.title: Beyond Smart
essays.summary: This essay argues that intelligence alone is not what made Einstein special - it was his ability to generate important new ideas. While being smart is a necessary precondition for innovation, many highly intelligent people never discover anything new, suggesting that other cultivable ingredients like obsessive interest, independent-mindedness, and writing ability are equally crucial.
key_concepts: gap between intelligence and new ideas
questions_answered: Why do so many smart people fail to discover anything new?
What ingredients beyond intelligence lead to new ideas?
Can the ability to have new ideas be cultivated?
Why does society overvalue intelligence versus actual innovation?

essays.title: Being a Noob
essays.summary: Paul Graham explores how the uncomfortable feeling of being a novice is actually inversely correlated with ignorance - the more you feel like a noob by exploring new territories, the more you actually learn. He argues that our evolutionary aversion to feeling incompetent, while useful in static hunter-gatherer societies, now holds us back in our rapidly changing world.
questions_answered: Why do we dislike feeling like a beginner?
Is feeling incompetent actually a sign of growth?
How does stepping outside comfort zones relate to learning?

essays.title: Apple's Mistake
essays.summary: Paul Graham critiques Apple's App Store approval process, arguing that its broken nature has severely damaged Apple's once-stellar reputation among programmers. He warns that the App Store has become an 'ongoing karma leak' that is turning programmers against Apple.
questions_answered: How has the App Store affected Apple's reputation?
Why do programmers view Apple differently now?
What is Apple's biggest mistake with developers?

essays.title: An NFT That Saves Lives
essays.summary: Paul Graham discusses a unique NFT launched by Noora Health, a nonprofit that teaches new mothers in South Asian hospitals how to care for their babies. The NFT auction proceeds will directly fund life-saving programs, with measurable impact of saving 9 babies per 1000 live births at a cost of $1,235 per life saved.
questions_answered: How can NFTs be used for charitable purposes?
What is the measurable impact of Noora Health's programs?
How much does it cost to save a life through maternal education?

essays.title: An Alternative Theory of Unions
essays.summary: Paul Graham argues that high-paying union manufacturing jobs of the mid-20th century were not a result of heroic labor movements, but rather a temporary aberration caused by rapidly growing manufacturing companies overpaying for reliable workers, similar to how tech startups during the Internet Bubble overpaid for consultants. The decline of unions today reflects a natural correction rather than a loss of moral courage.
questions_answered: Why were union manufacturing jobs so well-paid in the mid-20th century?
Why are unions declining today?
Was the era of strong unions sustainable?
How do rapidly growing industries approach labor costs?

essays.title: Alien Truth
essays.summary: An exploration of truths that would be universal across all intelligent life forms, not just limited to mathematics and physics. Graham argues that principles like controlled experiments, Occam's razor, and the ability to improve through practice would likely be shared with alien intelligences, and that searching for these 'alien truths' is essentially what philosophy should be.
questions_answered: What truths would all intelligent beings share?
What should be the goal of philosophy?
How can we identify the most fundamental and universal truths?

essays.title: After the Ladder
essays.summary: Paul Graham examines the shift from climbing corporate ladders to building startups, arguing that while this creates the appearance of increased economic inequality, the financial differences aren't as dramatic as they seem since the old system's job security had hidden monetary value. He explains how corporate takeovers in the 1980s destroyed the implicit contract between companies and employees, leading to today's more liquid but riskier entrepreneurial model.
questions_answered: Why did the corporate ladder model disappear?
How does job security factor into real economic inequality?
What are the tradeoffs between corporate careers and startups?

essays.title: After Credentials
essays.summary: This essay observes how the importance of educational credentials in determining one's future has diminished in the US over the past 25 years. Graham contrasts the credential-obsessed culture of South Korea with the evolving American system where performance increasingly matters more than where you went to college.
questions_answered: How has the importance of credentials changed in the US?
Does college still matter as much as it used to?
What determines success more now - credentials or performance?

essays.title: A Word to the Resourceful
essays.summary: Graham identifies that the most successful startups have resourceful founders who can understand implications and execute independently, while unsuccessful startups have founders who are hard to talk to and avoid uncomfortable implications. The key trait distinguishing successful founders is conversational resourcefulness - the ability to understand all implications of advice and chase them down, even when uncomfortable.
questions_answered: What distinguishes successful startup founders from unsuccessful ones?
Why are some founders hard to talk to?
How does resourcefulness manifest in founder behavior?

essays.title: A Way to Detect Bias
essays.summary: This essay presents a method for detecting bias in selection processes by analyzing the performance of selected candidates. If a selection process is biased against a particular group, members of that group who are selected will outperform others because they had to be better to overcome the bias.
questions_answered: How can you detect bias without knowing the applicant pool?
What does it mean for a selection process to be biased?
Is there bias against female founders in venture capital?
How can third parties detect bias in organizations?

essays.title: A Unified Theory of VC Suckage
essays.summary: Paul Graham explains how the venture capital business model inherently creates problematic behaviors, arguing that VCs act like 'jerks' not because they're bad people, but because managing huge funds requires them to make enormous investments that lead to paranoia, micromanagement, and misaligned incentives with founders.
questions_answered: Why do VCs behave badly toward founders?
How does the VC business model affect startups?
Why do VCs push for huge investments and high valuations?
What are the downsides of taking large VC funding?

essays.title: A Project of One's Own
essays.summary: This essay explores the unique excitement and productivity that comes from working on projects of your own choosing, comparing it to the difference between skating and walking. Graham argues that this self-directed work, while not always happy, leads to feeling truly alive and engaged, and that much of history's great work has been done by people working in this mode.
questions_answered: What makes working on personal projects different from regular work?
How can we preserve the excitement of childhood projects in adult work?
Why do programmers often rewrite existing software?
What's the relationship between personal projects and startup success?

essays.title: A Local Revolution?
essays.summary: This essay explores the possibility that the startup revolution might remain permanently localized to a few centers like Silicon Valley, unlike previous economic revolutions that spread widely. Graham argues that because startups are more of a social phenomenon requiring expertise communities rather than just technical knowledge, and because there's no inherent market need for localized versions, startup hubs will spread very slowly if at all.
questions_answered: Will the startup revolution spread globally like previous economic revolutions?
Why are startups concentrated in certain geographic locations?
Can governments successfully create new startup hubs?
What factors determine where startup ecosystems thrive?

essays.title: A Fundraising Survival Guide
essays.summary: A comprehensive guide on how to survive the brutal fundraising process for startups, explaining why raising money is so difficult and providing practical strategies to navigate investor interactions. The essay emphasizes maintaining morale, keeping low expectations, and continuing product development while fundraising.
questions_answered: Why is fundraising so difficult for startups?
How should founders approach the fundraising process?
When should a startup bootstrap vs raise money?
How to maintain company momentum during fundraising?
